div.p: 1. V:30. Saturday.

There was a thunder gust last evening shortly before midnight, contradicting the proverb that the month of March goes out like a Lamb: and this morning was cold and blustering more like the first of March than of April— Mr Powers had called at my house yesterday and requested that I would give him a short final sitting for my bust. I went accordingly at nine O’Clock this morning, and he gave the last touches to his waste mould of clay; taken from the soil of this city; and which he says is the best moulding clay in the world— This is probably the last time that a counterfeit presentment of me will be made in this world; and likenesses enough of my face and person will be left to survive me— My likeness has been taken in the course of my life by sixteen Painters, five Sculptors, and one medalist— Stweart, King, Harding and Durand have painted me twice.— My face has been copied in my sixteenth and my seventieth year— They show what I am, and what I was. John Cranch was with Powers— From his studio, I went to the Library at the Capitol, where I met Leonard Jarvis late a member of the House of Representatives from Maine, but who declined a re-election to the 25th
25th Congress, and who remains here an invalid waiting for permission from his physician to travel northward home— I had some conversation with him— We disagree in almost all our opinions; but are yet upon terms like those of Dr Johnson with Gilbert Walmsley. He said to me that S. L. Southard while Secretary of the Navy had purchased of Thomas Newton lands no otherwise described in the Deed than as in the neighbourhood of the Navy hospital at Norfolk, for which he had paid Newton 8000 dollars, and for which he thought Southard ought to be impeached. I told Jarvis that I knew nothing of the facts; but that I had such confidence in the integrity of Southard and of Newton, that I would stake any thing upon the issue that no wrong to the public had been done by the contract whatever— I went into the Law Library chamber, and examined the act of Parliament 5. George 4. C. 113 containing the revised British code for the abolition of the Slave-trade; and the Treaties of Great-Britain then existing with Spain, Portugal and the Netherlands for the suppression of the trade— I read also the decision of Lord Stowell in the case of the Slave, Grace, in the second volume of Haggart’s Admiralty Reports— These are both cited in Mr Van Buren’s Note to Lord Palmerston, on the case of the Slaves liberated at New-Providence, after the wreck of the Comet— The British Slave-emancipation Acts I cannot find in the Library— The decision of Lord Stowell in the case of the Slave Grace, is very remarkable— He gives a history of the abolition of Slavery in England effected by the mere fiat of Lord Mansfield in the case of the Negro Somersett only 22 years after a directly contrary decision by Lord Hardwick— Lord Stowell leans hard against the decision of Lord Mansfield, though he dares not reverse it; and he absolutely ridicules the boast of Britons that the soil of their Country will not bear the foot of a Slave— The whole tenour of his argument is anti-abolitionist, and was adapted to discountenance the progress of the abolitionist Spirit in England, which nevertheless very soon after that judgment accomplished the emancipation Laws in the British West-India Colonies— This was forced upon the British Government by the irresistible current of public opinion; and this decision of Lord Stowell’s was among the last struggles against it— The decision was, that although a West-India Slave, landing in England, was emancipated while residing there, yet by being carried back to the land of Slavery, she was restored to her servitude and to her master— I returned home about an hour before dinner. After dinner there came Mr Whitcomb, heretofore a subaltern Custom-house Officer at Boston, and persevering applicant for an Office here— He had removed
removed to the State of Vermont, where he had purchased a farm; but is now offered a Clerkship under Albion K. Parris, sometime Governor of the State of Maine, but now first Auditor of the Treasury— Mr Whitcomb said he came to thank me, for having recommended him a year or two ago, for an appointment under the Commissioner of the general Land-Office— He enquired if Mr Alexander H. Everett was here, and said he was not at Boston when he came through there this day fortnight— A man by the name of Shea, and his Son, from Baltimore, came with a subscription paper for a volume of Poems, to which I declined to put my name— He asked me then to accept the volume, which I also declined— Mr Francis Bartlett came, and I went with him to the House of Mr Dickerson the Secretary of the Navy, to whom he submitted his claim to be restored to the year 1832. instead of 1833 for his rank as passed midshipman— Mr Dickerson took his papers and said he would consider his claim— Thomas J. Frye dined and spent the Evening here— Whist.
2. VI. Sunday.

Heard this morning at the Presbyterian Church Mr Fowler from Isaiah 53.6.—“and the Lord hath laid on him the iniquity of us all.” A discourse thoroughly calvinistical upon the doctrine of vicarious atonement by sacrifice of blood. A doctrine to me so utterly senseless and absurd, that I cannot without effort sit and hear it preached with Patience— Mr Fowler brought in the whole story of the Levitical laws of atonement and the goat Hazazel, which the children had been reading to me this morning; but the ceremonial of sending the scape-goat into the wilderness laden with all the sins of the People was merely symbolical; as a supplication of forgiveness for past transgressions, by a people who had no conception of any other than temporal punishments— How the scape-goat Hazazel, can be construed into a type of the sufferings and death of Jesus, not only for all past but for all future sins to the end of the world is to me incomprehensible and odious. To punish one man for the committed sins of another is revolting enough to the natural sense of Justice; but that a man crucified two thousand years ago, for preaching glory to God and Peace on Earth, and immortal life to man, should have been punished for my sins committed two thousand years after his death is such a confusion of all moral principle that I marvel, how it should ever have entered into the brain of any human being. The whole calvinistic doctrine of atonement, is a libel upon human reason— Robert Buchanan came in from Baltimore, where he has been spending a week, and dined with us; as did his brother Thomas J. Frye. After dinner I went with Mary-Louisa to St. John’s Church and heard Mr
Mr Hawley read prayers for the first Sunday after Easter, and preach from Isaiah 57—“the high and lofty one that inhabiteth eternity whose name is holy”—part of a verse— The Sermon was upon Eternity; and it was an occasional Sermon upon the death of Mrs William Ramsay, who died very suddenly yesterday morning a few days after child bearing.— It was much like all the rest of Mr Hawley’s funeral discourses— Mary and Elizabeth spent the Evening at Mrs Frye’s, and Mrs Adams went there to return with them home— I wrote to N. Biddle, and read the printed Letter of Gerrit Smith, to the Revd. James Smylie late stated Clerk of the Presbytery of Mississippi, author of book in defence of Slavery to which this Letter is an answer— I have read scarcely any thing upon this controversy, and am quite incompetent to discuss it myself.— I come to the conclusion, without examining the premises.— I have an abhorrence of Slavery; but how bad it is no one can imagine without understanding the details— Smylie defends Slavery as an institution sanctioned by the Scriptures.— But the extermination of the Canaanitish Nations was also sanctioned by the Scriptures— The punishment of death was prescribed for a multitude of what we should consider very trivial offences— The theory of the rights of man was then utterly unknown— And Mr G. Smith shews that the servitude of that time was a milder condition than the Slavery of the present age and of this Country— This subject of Slavery, to my great sorrow and mortification is absorbing all my faculties.
3. V:30. Monday

Morning visit from Leonard Jarvis, who told me, that the Report of A. Stevenson’s having negotiated with the British Government a Treaty, in which is included indemnity for the Slaves taken from the Comet, Encomium and Enterprize was premature— That the Government here had no advice of the conclusion of such a Treaty— Notwithstanding which I have no doubt that such a Treaty is expected, and think there is a great probability that it will be obtained.— A delay of six years in giving an answer to demands arising from the execution of a Law, is proof satisfactory that there was no good answer to give; and this inability to meet a claim, is a demonstration that it must ultimately be admitted— Judge Cranch’s two youngest daughters, and his son Edward were here— And Isaac Hull Adams just from Boston, on his way to Savannah where he is going upon engineering service— Robert Buchanan also dined with us, somewhat annoyed at a recent order to his regiment to repair to fort Gibson—far westward— I walked round the Capitol Hill before dinner, and
passed the Evening at whist— I wrote to Anthony Collamore, Pembroke, and copied and finished some lines to Elizabeth De Wint— She had left with Mary and Elizabeth C. Adams a request that I would write some lines for her, and it has been several days hanging upon my Spirits—
4. V. Tuesday.

It was my intention to have spent two or three hours of this morning in the Library of Congress, but I was disappointed first by sundry calls of business and a necessary visit to the bank of the Metropolis, and then by answering a Letter also upon business received yesterday from my Son— My only walk for exercise was after dinner, and towards evening twilight, round the seven buildings cold and cheerless. Isaac Hull Adams left us immediately after dinner, to take the rail-way Cars for Baltimore; and thence the Steamboat to Norfolk on his way to Savannah— There came an Irishman from Mr Peter Force the Mayor of the City, to shew me a remonstrance to be signed by many inhabitants of the City against the building now in process of erection for the Departments of State and of the Treasury, and which they complain will block up F. Street, and obstruct the view in the Pennsylvania Avenue, from the Capitol down to the President’s house— The strange part of the business is that the building is already built up nine or ten feet from the ground at a very heavy expense, and that the only alternative now is to persevere, or to pull down and rebuild in another direction. After dinner Dr Causin called upon me, and said that Mr William Otis who has been nearly a whole year confined in the prison of this City for debt was now in such a state of health with a rhumatism, that unless shortly removed from the jail he would die— That he had finally consented to call his creditors together to make over his property to trustees for their benefit, and Dr Causin wished me to call at the prison, and advise him to agree to their terms— He said that the Marshal had given directions that Mr Otis should be supplied with every thing necessary for his comfort that could be furnished him there; and that he was attended by two men, a black and a white man, his fellow prisoners in the same chamber to nurse him— But in that confinement and with that atmosphere he was perishing, and unless liberated could not long survive— I told Dr. Causin that I had been last week to see Mr Otis, and would go and see him again; and advise him to make the assignment necessary to obtain his liberation— Mrs John Martin Baker and her daughter were here to ask my advise how they were to proceed to prove that Mrs Baker’s father Coll Weissenfels was an Officer of the Revolutionary
Revolutionary War; a fact of which I have no personal knowledge whatever— Mrs Baker said they had possessed a Letter from Genl. Van Cortland under whom Coll. Weissenfels served, attesting all his service, but it had been put into the hands of the late President Jackson, and not returned, and they now had nothing but a copy— Mr Baker is now Consul of the United States at Rio de Janeiro; but they expect him home soon.— Mr Hunter the Marshal of this District brought me an order from the District Court of the United States at Baltimore to Summon me to attend there next Monday as a Witness in a case in which Reuben M Whitney is Plaintiff, and Leakin Defendant.— Dr Randall and Robert Buchanan were here this Evening.
5. V:30. Wednesday

New Moon— Sun eclipsed invisible— Snow all the morning which melted as it fell, with cheerless chilly weather. Mrs Tudor sent me a note requesting me to call at her house which I did— She and her daughter Mrs Stewart had the Journals and Letter Books of her deceased Son William Tudor, of which they wish to make a pecuniary speculation by selling them to a bookseller for publication— She wanted me to write an introduction or preliminary discourse, which I willingly agreed to do; but she did not like to part with her manuscripts—only part of them at a time so that the publication may be made in successive volumes, one at a time— Mrs Stewart read to me two passages from the journal—one a picturesque description of the cordillares from one of their summits the other a musing of moral reflections upon the death of an old Peruvian at the age of nearly one hundred years— While at Mrs Tudor’s I was sent for to return to my house where I was sent for to return to my house, and there found Luigi Persico, who has obtained from President Van Buren a contract copied from that which he made with me, for a group of two Statues—Columbus and the Indian, for which he is to receive 4000 dollars a year for four successive years, and 5000 dollars the 5th. year. He told me he should go to-morrow, to embark as soon as possible for Italy.— He said he had given to the Librarian of Congress the order to keep my bust subject to my order, but as I declined accepting it, he would write to the Librarian, requesting him to retain it in the Library, and request the acceptance of it by Congress to be kept there. He took leave of me with grateful affection expressing the hope to see me again upon his return five years hence—of which the omniscient eye alone can see the result— I had also a visit before dinner and another after dinner from Mr Todd; the son of Mrs Madison, having some reference to the manuscript pages of Mr Madison for the purchase of which an appropriation was made by Congress at
at their last Session— Mr Forsyth insists upon having all the papers—but there are a number of them, of which copies have been retained and some which have been sent to Europe— There seems to be some hazard of misunderstanding as to the extent of property in the papers to be retained by Mr Madison’s legal representatives, after the purchase for the public, and I advised Mr Todd, as a friend to his mothers character in future and to avoid the possibility of unkind surmises to be explicit with Mr Forsyth, by informing him in writing of all the papers retained— Which he said he would do— I recommended that one or two Sentences should be erased from a Letter of 22. Octr. 1782. Which he promised— Thomas J. Frye came here to dine this day and stays— Evening at Whist—
6. V:30. Thursday—

I have had two months upon hand a Letter from E. Price Greenleaf, which I had never yet found time to answer— And having been yesterday occupied with one to Gerrit Smith, I commenced that to Mr Greenleaf this morning; but could not get through it in the course of the day— Mr Lewis Johnson called upon me and said he was a creditor of Mr William Otis though not one of those at whose suit he was confined in prison— That Mr Otis last Summer had consented to execute a deed of trust to him of his property for the benefit of his creditors, upon condition that he should give large security for the execution of the trust; which he had agreed to do; but when the papers had all been drawn up by Mr W. L. Brent, and ready for execution—Mr Otis had changed his mind and declined executing them— He was now however very ill, and was desirous of seeing me— I told him I was going to see him in consequence of a call upon me by Dr Causin— I went accordingly to the prison and saw him—he was very weak, much emaciated, and his countenance much changed since I saw him the week before last— I told him that Mr Johnson had called upon me, and Dr Causin, who thought it indispensable that he should be removed from the prison to a more comfortable place— He asked my advice what to do, and I advised him immediately to execute the deed of trust to Mr Johnson, who bears a very good character; and I urged him to have it done forthwith so that he might be removed to a suitable lodging before the end of the week. He expressed a wish that I would consent to be his trustee, which I told him I would be with pleasure, but that I could render him better service by pressing his claim at the next Session of Congress as a member, which I could not do if I should be his trustee— He finally consented to make
make the assignment to Mr Johnson, and requested me to call at his shop in the Pennsylvania avenue, and let him know. I went to the Capitol and enquired at the Clerk’s Office, for the printed document of William Tudor’s correspondence from Peru; but it had not yet come from the Printers Office— I got the sheets of the Journal containing the last days of January, and the first week in February beyond which the printing has not yet reached— Johnson was gone to Baltimore, and Burch is yet confined to his house but convalescent— I went into the Library and spent an hour and a half there in searching Pope’s works for Matthew Concanen and Francis Chartres, types of Roger B. Taney and Reuben M. Whitney.— I found Concanen in the Dunciad, but could not find the epitaph upon Chartres— It seems that Pope found it dangerous to speak too roughly of Chartres— Returning home I called at Mr Lewis Johnson’s house and informed him that Mr Otis had consented to execute the deed of trust to him, and he promised to set about it immediately.— Robert Buchanan and Thomas J. Frye dined with us— Mrs Stewart came in after dinner with another posthumous claim of allowance upon the accounts in Peru of William Tudor and left with me a book of expences upon which he had entered certain charges for traveling expences, which she wishes to have claimed at the Department of State. Robert Buchanan and Thomas J. Frye spent the evening here— They had cards below, but I passed the Evening in my chamber, writing.
7. V:15. Friday

Finished the Letter to E. Price Greenleaf, and wrote one to a Committee of the Phoenix Society of Hamilton College at Clinton in the State of New-York, the object of which Society is stated to be the improvement of its members in every species of Literature— The Committee inform me that I have been elected an honorary member of the Society, and with my answer of acceptance I have added some observations on its declared object— There are at this time in the United States eighty three universities and colleges. 13. of which are in New-England, six in New-York— Ten besides the Girard college in Pennsylvania, and nine in the State of Ohio. The oldest of them all is Harvard University, which in its organization is the model from which most of the others have been adopted— At almost all of them select Societies among the Students are formed of which the Phi Beta Kappa is the prototype— This institution has had an extraordinary influence upon the Literature and History of the Country— Many of these select Societies of Students elect honorary members and
and several of them have done me that honour— Among the rest this Phoenix Society— But I am an unworthy member of them all; for I have done nothing for any of them; and really do not know to which of them I belong— I had a long morning visit from Mr Fendall, in which we had much conversation about the colonization Society— He has engaged some person to negotiate the affair of the fugitive Slave from Alexandria, concerning whom I have an unanswered Letter from Mr Charles Gilpin of Philadelphia. Mr Fendall left with me two numbers of the Liberia Herald, a monthly newspaper, printed at Monrovia— I called twice at the Office of the Secretary of War, and the second time, found Mr Poinsett— I had a Letter from Mr Mace Smith renewing the solicitation for a warrant of Cadet, for his Son Horace Smith, and I requested that his name might be entered, on the books with my recommendation; he being only 14 years of age the 10th. of next Month. Mr Poinsett declined, and said by the regulations of the Department no Cadet could be admitted under 16. years of age, and he must be nominated by the member of the House of Representatives from the Congressional District to which he belongs. I asked Mr Poinsett if it was true that A. Stevenson had concluded a Treaty with the British Government—he said they had no knowledge of it whatever—and intimated that there was very little prospect of such an event. Robert Buchanan was here before dinner— At the dusk of evening I received a Letter from Mr Lewis Johnson, informing me that William Otis died in prison this afternoon. I did not think him yesterday so near his end—though very ill, and extremely weak. Mr Johnson went yesterday to have the assignment which he had agreed to make, executed; but he was already too feeble to accomplish it— May he meet in the other world that Mercy, which has not been extended to him in this— I employed the latter part of the Evening in writing.
8. V. Saturday

I read this morning in the Manuscripts of Mr Madison the Report of the Speech of Alexander Hamilton, in the Convention of 1787. upon presenting his plan for a Constitution of the United States— The Speech occupied a whole day, and was of great ability— The plan was theoretically better than that which was adopted— But energetic and approaching the British Constitution far closer, and such as the public Opinions of that day never would have tolerated— Still less would it be endured by the democratic spirit of the present age, far more democratic than that— For after half a century
century of inextinguishable wars between the democracy of the European race and its Monarchy and Aristocracy, the democracy is yet in the ascendant and gaining victory after victory over the porcelain of the race— If Hamilton were now living he would not dare in an assembly of Americans, even with closed doors to avow the opinions of this Speech, or to present such a plan even as a speculation— I called at Mr Lewis Johnson’s but he was not at home— I then went to the Marshal’s Office at the City-Hall to enquire concerning the unfortunate man who died yesterday at the prison— I learnt that his disease had been of long standing—contracted before his confinement, though that has probably hastened his decease— The Marshal had made all the necessary arrangements for his interment which was fixed for this afternoon—between 70 and 80. dollars were found in his pocket-book, which with his trunk of papers and effects were sealed up and in charge of the Marshal’s deputy— A coroner’s inquest had been held over his body— I went over to the prison, and saw his corpse laid out, on the same bed where I had conversed with him the day before yesterday— The gaoler told me that before his decease the consolations and encouragements of religion had been administered to him by Mr Noble, Minister of the first Presbyterian Church. That he retained his Senses to the last moment, and died twenty minutes before six O’Clock yesterday afternoon— I called at Mr Powers’s studio, and saw the busts in plaister which he has taken including that of Genl. Gaines and my own. Thence I went to the Library of Congress, and spent an hour with Pope— I found the epitaph of Chartres, which is in a Note to the Epistle on the use of riches.— I took up the 20th. Volume of Howell’s State trials, and noticed the case of the Negro Somersett, but found the Report so long, that I could not even begin upon it; but I must take it up another time— Returning home I called again at Mr Lewis Johnson’s but he was not at home— He came however to my house after dinner and told me that he proposed to take out Administration upon the Estate of William Otis being one of his creditors— Robert Buchanan and Thomas J. Frye dined with us— Evening partly at whist, and afterwards writing.
9. V:30. Sunday.

I went this morning with Elizabeth C. and Midshipman John Quincy Adams to the Unitarian Church and heard Dr Follen late professor of the German language at Harvard University, now an unitarian preacher at the City of New-York, preach from Ephesians 4:28. “Let him that stole steal no more; but rather let him labour, working with his hands the thing which is good, that he may have to give to him that needeth.” Three progressive virtues—Honesty, Industry—Charity a well
a well divided and earnestly argued plain and practical moral discourse, emphatically delivered— Dr Follen though a native German, speaking and writing English so that the foreign accent is scarcely perceptible. He gave notice that the first of a course of lectures upon the Unitarian doctrines and principles would be delivered at half-past seven O’Clock this Evening— Mrs Frye was here before church this morning—and Robert Buchanan and Thomas J. Frye dined with us— After dinner I went with my two Grand children to St. John’s Church and heard Mr Hawley, from Numbers 6.23. “Speak unto Aaron, and unto his sons, saying, On this wise ye shall bless the children of Israel, saying unto them. 24 The Lord bless thee, and keep thee: 25. The Lord make his face shine upon thee, and be gracious unto thee; 26. The Lord lift up his countenance upon thee, and give thee peace. 27. And they shall put my name upon the children of Israel, and I will bless them.” There was something peculiar in this Sermon— It was upon the efficacy of a blessing pronounced in a certain form of words: an idea to which this express injunction of God to Moses does countenance— Mr Hawley urged also the efficacy of the form of blessing used in the episcopal church in dismissing the congregation— And he assured them that the absolution and remission of sins prescribed in the book of common prayer, was effectual for the remission of the sins of all true penitents— I did not consider this as a claim of the Ministers of the Episcopal church, though it is an article of faith among the roman catholics— The Ministers of the Episcopal Church declare and pronounce that God absolveth all those who are truly penitent; but it is the penitence that obtains absolution and not the proclamation of it by the Priest. It is perhaps even too much for man to say, that God pardoneth and absolveth, all those who truly repent— Man may and ought to pray that all true penitent may be pardoned—but pardon belongs to God alone; and the Priest cannot know to whom it will, or will not be extended— I had more than two months since, received a Letter from Professor John G. Palfrey, at Cambridge, proposing to me to write an Article to be published in the North-American Review, upon international Copy-rights I do not feel prepared to undertake such an Essay— The whole theory and doctrine of copy rights being exceedingly loose and unsettled— I answered Dr. Palfrey’s Letter, this day, and opened some of the sources of discussion upon international copy-right which is encumbered with considerable difficulties— I have not absolutely declined writing the Article, but have asked for more time and consultation. There is certainly an equitable claim of compensation to eminent foreign authors, but the right of property in thought must be confined within narrow limits— I packed up this evening my trunk for my unwilling journey to Baltimore to-morrow.
10. V:30. Monday— From Washington to Baltimore— Barnum’s Hotel.

At half past 9. O’Clock this morning with my nephew Midshipman John Quincy Adams I entered the Railway Cars, and a quarter before twelve at Noon, landed at Baltimore we immediately came to Barnum’s Hotel, where I took a bed chamber— I enquired immediately for the Court-house, and upon being directed to it went and found a City Court in Session, and Reverdy Johnson arguing a cause— Upon enquiring further I found the place where the Circuit Court of the United States holds their Sessions, but the Court had already adjourned— I then went to the Office of the Chronicle Newspaper, where they sent for General Leakin the former editor of the paper, and when he came, he gave me a printed slip from the Chronicle of 21. July 1832—being the article which Reuben M. Whitney, charges as libellous, and for which his damages are laid at fifty thousand dollars. The Article charges him directly with perjury, founded upon his testimony and the counter testimony of the Officers of the bank before the Committee of investigation of the House of Representatives, at Philadelphia in April 1832— I enquired if I might expect to be examined and released to-morrow.— Mr Leakin told me he would consult with his counsel and see me this Evening— Returning to Barnum’s I found Mr Lloyd N. Rogers there, and he spent half an hour with me in my chamber— I dined at the Ordinary with about 80 strangers at one table— After dinner I found the house of Mr Gorham Brooks, having met him in the street as I was seeking it— He turned back with me, and made an hour’s visit to Mrs Brooks with whom was Mrs George Calvert— Mr and Mrs Brooks both invited me to come and lodge at their House, and I told them that if I should remain here longer than to-morrow, I should perhaps accept their invitation— I returned to my chamber at Barnum’s; wrote to my wife—read the introductory chapter to George Tucker’s life of Thomas Jefferson, supped at the Ladies ordinary, the tables in the other room being crowded with 130 persons, the accession of about fifty being of travellers arriving from North and South since dinner— Mr Barnum himself being absent in North-Carolina— At half past eight in the Evening Mr Leakin, with Mr Gwinn his former Partner, Mr Meredith and Mrhis Council came, and I conversed with them on the prospects of the time when the trial will come on— Mr Meredith said it could not possibly be to-morrow, nor probably any day this week— He said also that the parties on both sides were anxious for a trial and the counsel on both sides had asked the court to fix a day for the trial, which the Court had refused— I finally agreed to stay here till to-morrow afternoon— To attend the Court to-morrow Morning when another effort may be made to fix a day for the
trial, and if that should fail, I return to Washington to morrow evening, and Mr Meredith will send me notice a day in advance, when I must attend again— Mr Meredith promised to call on me at 10 O’Clock to-morrow Morning— Mr Payton Gay called on me, while I was engaged with these Gentlemen; and I invited him to call again to-morrow. Robert Buchanan came in with the Cars, and brought me a Message from Mrs Adams, that Wilson, and his wife had left the house, and that she wanted instructions— I wrote her accordingly a second Letter— John Quincy after visiting his brother Midshipman Barney came in, and retired to bed, as I did after reading till 11. in the life of Jefferson.
11. V. Tuesday. From Baltimore to Washington

My nephews departed this morning by the Boats. John Quincy Adams for Philadelphia, going on to Quincy, and Robert Buchanan to Annapolis— At 10 O’Clock Mr Meredith called and I went with him to the Circuit Court of the United States held by Roger B. Taney, now Chief Justice of the United States, and Upton Heath, the District judge— In the case of Reuben M. Whitney against Leakin and Barnes the parties were not ready for trial, and after consultation between the Counsel, it was agreed that it should be brought on if possible next week, if possible on Monday, but Mr Meredith thought my testimony would probably not be required before Wednesday. I determined therefore to return to Washington this Evening— On leaving the Court-house I went with Mr Meredith to his house, where he gave me to read a manuscript copy of a Letter from the late Major Henry Lee to a friend of his named Brown in Virginia, whom he requests to send a copy of it to Mr John Tyler then a member of the Senate of the United States from Virginia.— Henry Lee an abandoned and scarified character, but a writer of very considerable talent and power, had in reward for treachery to me, and libels against me, and of sycophancy to the late President Jackson, been appointed by him during the recess of the Senate, Consul General of the United States at Algiers in 1829. Upon his nomination to the Senate, he had been rejected for profligacy of character, and chiefly by the influence of Mr Tyler— In the interval he had been at Algiers; was there when the City was taken by the French army, and was said to have made a profitable speculation of his official privilege in covering property with the aegis of Neutrality— This has however has been contradicted— On being displaced from his office, he went to Paris and lived there till in January last he died; it is said of the grippe or influenza— In Paris he pursued the occupation of a man of Letters, publishing pamphlets of criticism and controversy, among which one attack upon my Eulogy on La Fayette; which he sent to the Editor of the New-York American Charles King— King a man under greater personal obligations to me than any man living, published Lee’s lampoon, and then wrote me that the columns of his paper were open to me, if I chose to answer Henry Lee— But among
among Lee’s literary labours was a life of Napoleon Bonaparte, of which he had published one volume and had another in preparation—a work of great promise and small performance, making of Napoleon an idol— This Letter to Brown was evidently intended for publication— It had been preceded by a Letter demanding directly or indirectly of Mr Tyler his reasons for voting against Lee’s appointment of Consul to Algiers— Mr Tyler had denied his right to make this enquiry, but had assigned Lee’s vicious character as his motive for voting against his appointment. This Letter is Lee’s reply to that answer of Tyler— He assumes that the only ground of Tyler’s objection to his character was that he had committed adultery with his wife’s sister— He then affirms that Mr Tyler had been a constant, undeviating, devoted admirer and supporter of Thomas Jefferson throughout life; thinking him not only qualified but pre-eminently entitled to the highest office of the Nation, and had pronounced upon him after his death an enthusiastic panegyric; yet Thomas Jefferson for twelve years in succession had exerted all his faculties, being himself a married man, to debauch the wife of his most intimate friend John Walker; abusing for that purpose of the opportunities afforded him by sacred and confidential trusts— He affirms morever that Mr Jefferson had several coloured children by his own Slaves— And he concludes that Mr Tyler’s double measure of morality between Jefferson attempts at seduction, and his Lee’s accomplished purpose, arose merely from Jefferson’s failure, and his own success— The Letter is of ten folio pages, and written in the most ambitious style; as if he was all the time studying to write elegant periods— He says that he has all the facts detailed in Jefferson’s own handwriting, in correspondence with his father, who undertook to reconcile Jefferson with Mr and Mrs Walker and succeeded— This unlucky episode in the life of Jefferson, was used against him by the federalists in his life time as much as they dared—but they spared him to escape the back handed stroke upon Hamilton— Mr George Tucker’s idea of biography, may be inferred from the fact that he takes no notice of this blot in the Life of Jefferson. It is as if one should write the life of David, and leave out the whole Story of Uriah the Hittite and his wife— Perhaps Plutarch’s rule of biography will justify the pretermission of incidents so disgraceful to the memory of Mr Jefferson— I returned from Mr Meredith’s to my chamber at Barnum’s—received visits from Mr Gorham Brooks, from Mr Calvert, Robert Gilmer and John Barney— At half past two I went to Mr Gorham Brooks’s and dined— Mr Meredith, Mr Calvert and Mr Gilmer were of the party— At half past four Mrs Brooks’s took me in her carriage to the deposit place of the railway cars, where I took my passage for Washington, and at a quarter past seven alighted at the foot of the Capitol Hill— P. Mauro was a fellow passenger—going to settle in the western Country— I found Mrs W. S. Smith at our House— Mr Smith came in shortly after; and afterwards Mr Fendall; who told me the Man at Alexandria had taken the ransom for his run-away Slave— Whist.
12. V.30. Wednesday.

The day passed without interruption, but I did nothing till the Evening— My Grand-child Mary-Louisa was sick this morning which prevented me from hearing her and her sister read— Mrs. Adams went and dined with her Sister Mrs Frye—and Mary and Elizabeth C Adams spent the Evening there— Before dinner I walked to the race-ground beyond the Columbian College— I had not been there to my recollection within the last two years— Great part of the grounds on the way are not enclosed, and the slashes as they were called are all ploughed up and cleared off— And many of the old Oaks in the neighbourhood of the race-ground, are levelled and stretched their length upon the soil— Returning home I met the President Van-Buren, and his Son and Mr Forsyth, riding out on horseback— In the evening I wrote part of a Letter in answer to one of 30. Decr last from William Plumer junr. I consider it as a wasted day—
13. VI:15. Thursday

The children, recommenced their morning reading to me, with the 17th. chapter of Numbers—their mother was taken unwell and confined to her chamber all the day— The Revd. Dr Follen, the German Unitarian Clergyman, paid me a morning visit, and I had a long conversation with him upon the unitarian doctrines, and upon the Covenants of the old and new Testaments, which seem to me to sanction the political principle that by the Law of Nature all legitimate Government is founded in compact— I asked him if he had considered the influence first upon the History of the Jews through the old and new Testament, next upon the Christian Religion—thirdly upon the theory of human rights and the foundations of Government of this primary historical fact— He said he had not, and that it opened to him an entirely new view of the Scriptures— I believe this is the case with many others, and that I should do well to write a Dissertation or Lyceum Lecture upon it. The Scriptures represent man, as having at his creation a Law prescribed to him by his Creator— He is placed in Eden thereto remain in a happy state of connubial felicity, upon one condition— This is not a covenant, but a Law— The consent of Adam was not required to this Law—there is permission given him to subsist upon the fruit of all the trees, excepting one—but no promise is made to him; no covenant contracted with him— He violates the condition imposed upon him, and suffers expulsion from Paradise— There is no mention of a Covenant till after the Deluge, but immediately after that there is a Covenant, express and formal with Noah— This however is of a general character, and Noah himself by his curse upon Ham, deprived one third part of his descendants of the benefit of it. But the Covenants with Abraham are the most remarkable both for their solemnity and for their import— They were covenants of
of Religion and of Government— The first was at Sichem—Gen: 12.7. the second at Bethel—Gen. 13.14— The third and most solemn covenant is related in the 15th. chapter with all its particulars and specially stated, in the 18th. verse— The 4th. is related in the 17th. Chapter when Abraham was 99 years of age; and the covenant was sealed by the rite of circumcision— In the 22d. chapter—verses 17.18 the covenant is again renewed, after the call for the sacrifice of Isaac and its release. In Chapter 26. v. 2. the Covenant is repeated with Isaac— The blessing was afterwards transferred to Jacob, and the covenant renewed with him, in the dream at Bethel—ch. 28. v. 13.–20.22—and again ch: 35. v. 10 where his name is changed to Israel—and in ch. 46 v. 3. when he is ordered to go down to Egypt— The subsequent covenants were with the whole People, from that of Mount Sinai, down to the Babylonian captivity—and then came the New covenant of the gospel of Christ—all this is to be elucidated— I walked before dinner—stopped at the Office of the National Intelligencer where I saw Mr Gales, with whom was Mr Featherstonhaugh— Seaton afterwards came in— Evening disoccupied— There was a gathering this morning of perhaps a hundred labourers in the front yard of the President’s House— It was said their object was to remonstrate against working more than ten hours a day— It was said the President sent them word that he could not parlay with them so long as they should present themselves in that manner.
14. VI: Friday.

Mary continues quite unwell, and was confined to her chamber. I answered a Letter which has been several months on file, from William Plumer junr. of Epping, New-Hampshire; and one from Robert G. Rankin Secretary of the Executive Committee of the American Lyceum, New-York— They had adopted a Resolution inviting me to write an Essay upon some subject connected with the diffusion of knowledge and popular instruction in this Country to be read at the Meeting of the Lyceum at Philadelphia on the 5th. of next Month— After deliberating several weeks whether to comply with this invitation or not, I concluded to decline it, for the simple reason that I did not feel myself competent without longer notice and more leisure, to write upon that subject an Essay, the reading of which would give satisfaction to myself, or to those at whose request I should have written— Education in this Country as a subject of general interest, has not received a due portion of my attention— It is among the subjects which by a great proportion of the People has been considered as excluded from the consideration of the National Government, and belonging exclusively to the States. This is one of the great errors into which we have fallen, and my political life having been almost exclusively confined to the Legislation and executive Government of the Union, education has been in a great measure
measure discarded, from the subjects of my contemplation. I do not understand the subject therefore, and have not now time to make myself master of it— I ought not therefore to write for the public upon it. I called at the Department of War and delivered to the Secretary, Mr Poinsett a nomination by me of Zealous B. Tower, son of Nichols Tower of Cohassett, for admission to the military Academy at West Point, as a Cadet from the 12th. Congressional District of Massachusetts; and with it, a Letter from the father of the youth to the Secretary of War, soliciting the appointment— I had some conversation with Poinsett concerning the two dinners given since the close of the Session of Congress at Charleston one to the Senators Calhoun and Preston; and the other to Henry L. Pinckney, the late member of the House of Representatives of the United States from that City— Poinsett spoke very slightingly of the moral character of Pinckney— On my walk I called to visit Mr Leonard Jarvis at his lodgings, but he was not at home— We intermitted making fires in our bed-chamber and my cabinet—
15. V:30— Saturday

I found upon my files two Letters, making enquiries concerning certain claims for Pensions, which I had overlooked; one of them from Nelson B. Nye, Postmaster at East Wareham in my own District; in behalf of a man whom he does not name and for a claim of service whether in the revolutionary War, or of a later date he does not explain— The other is from C. J. Fox Alden of Meadville Crawford County, Pennsylvania, in behalf of Sarah M’Niel widow of a revolutionary Soldier— I took them both to the Office of the Commissioner of Pensions J. L. Edwards. He told me that he had given all the necessary information of the evidence requisite to sustain Mrs M’Niel’s claim, to Mr Galbraith late member from the District of Pennsylvania wherein she resides, and he gave me copies of the printed regulations of the War Department, to be observed for obtaining revolutionary or invalid Pensions. I met at his Office Mr Tomlinson late a Senator from Connecticut; who is still detained by the illness of his Son—consumptive.— Going from the Office, I met Mr Leonard Jarvis—who turned and walked with me to the Capitol— Mr Burch was not there, but confined to his house with a pulmonary complaint and a relapse— They gave me the sheets of the Journal of the House for the first fortnight in February. In the library, I took up the second Volume of Matthias’s Edition of Gray’s works, and wandered over it till the clock struck three and warned me to depart— I found in it the analysis of the writings of Plato, which I had no time to examine, but which I hope to find time to look into hereafter— I read some of his Letters to his mother, to his father, and to his friend West; and mused over that affecting incident that Gray’s Ode to Spring was sent by him when first written, in a Letter to West, who died just before he should have received it— I have literary tastes peculiar to myself, and the correctness of which I distrust, because they differ from the general voice— There is no Lyric Poet of antient or modern times, who so deeply affects my feelings as Gray— Every one of his Odes, is to me an inestimable jewel
jewel, and nothing in all Dr Johnson’s writings is so disgusting to me, as his criticisms upon them— The progress of Poesy and the Bard are the first and second Odes that ever were written— Dryden’s Alexander’s feast, Horace’s Carmen Saeculare and Collins’s Passions pari passu come after— Pindar’s Pythics are admirable and Anacreon is charming as a songster— But the progress of Poesy, is the point of the Pyramid—the first of Odes—as the Church yard is the first of Elegies— Yet I have read scarcely any thing of Gray, except the very small collection of his Poems, and these two thick Quarto’s of his works are almost all news to me— Why is it that I must reproach myself for an hour given to them as wasted time— I walked home— Mary dined below, but is yet unwell— Towards dusk I strolled out, and visited Mrs W. S. Smith— General and Mrs. Macomb came in while I was there— Mr Smith went this morning for New-York. Commodore Chauncey’s daughter died this morning.

16. V:15. Sunday.— Mary continues unwell, and kept her chamber, and her daughter Mary-Louisa, was confined the whole day to her bed— I attended Church alone— In the morning at the Presbyterian Church where Mr Fowler preached from Galatians 3.13. “Christ hath redeemed us from the curse of the law, being made a curse for us.”—another, and I hope the last of a series of discourses upon the doctrine of the atonement—vicarious punishment— I grow more and more impatient under this argumentation ad absurdum. That Christ should have died to atone for the sins of mankind before his birth and sufferings is intelligible, and as figuratively spoken is undoubtedly true— But that he should have died to atone for all the sins committed after his death to the end of the world, is giving the lie to all the faculties of human reason— And the more earnest and intense the sincerity of the preacher of such tenets appears the more manifest he makes the impotence of the rational faculty in man— Mr Fowler entertains no doubts respecting this Article of his creed— He urged it with the most implicit faith—but one sample of his reasoning will serve for all the rest—in maintaining with the most fervent anxiety, that only a small portion of mankind could be saved he quoted John 17.9. “I pray not for the world, but for them which thou hast given me; for they are thine.”— This certainly has the appearance of selection, and I was ruminating upon the force of this authority when Mr. Fowler to prove the universal goodness of God, quoted John 3.16. For God so loved the world, that he gave his only begotten son, &c—and the 17th. verse says—For God sent not his Son into the world to condemn the world; but that the world through him might be saved— The first Epistle of John 2.2 is still stronger—“And he is the propitiation for our sins; and not for ours only, but also for the sins of the whole world”— The weight of authority is therefore entirely against Mr Fowler’s argument of Selection— But perhaps the word world in these passages is used in different senses— In the last of the passages it evidently means all mankind—but the world that was to be saved; the whole world for whose sins he is the propitiation consists only of those who repent and
and believe his holy Gospel— Repentance and Faith are the conditions of Salvation by Christ, and that was the doctrine preached by the Apostles to their cotemporaries; sinners to be converted— The atonement of Christ for the sins of men, is figurative and metaphorical language, adopted from the Jewish sacrifices of the Passover— Christ is the paschal lamb; but it would be more rational to say that Christians worship a sheep—because Christ is called the lamb of God, than it is to say that my sins have been forgiven before they were committed, because Jesus was crucified at Jerusalem more than eighteen hundred years ago— According to the Levitical Law, the sacrifice of a lamb, made atonement for sin— That is to say, after the sacrifice, there was to be no further temporal punishment— There was no hereafter in the Law of Moses— Christ proclaimed the immortality of the Soul, and rewards and punishments after death— This doctrine indirectly demolished the whole system of the Mosaic Law, and for this Christ died upon the cross— So then as the paschal lamb, was an atonement for sins before committed, and released the Sinner who offered it, from further temporal punishment, so Jesus having died to establish the doctrine of immortal life and future retribution, is by analogy said to have substituted himself for the paschal lamb, and thus to have taken away the sins of the world.— After dinner at St. John’s Church, Mr Hawley read Prayers, for the 3d. Sunday after Easter and preached from Zechariah 12.10. “And I will pour upon the house of David, and upon the inhabitants of Jerusalem the spirit of grace and of supplications; and they shall look upon me, whom they have pierced, and they shall mourn for him, as one mourneth for his only son, and shall be in bitterness for him, as one that is in bitterness for his first born.” This last idea was the ruling one in his own mind; and he alluded feelingly to his own loss of a Son, sometime— How bitterly did his text bring to my Soul the repeated loss of mine!— After Church I went and visited Dr Huntt who is confined to his house, very ill, with a hectic cough after a bleeding at the lungs, and reduced to a skeleton— I fear irrecoverable—but he said none of his family had ever been consumptive and that he had now two uncles living, upwards of ninety years old— He conversed as cheerfully upon men and things as usual. I wrote morning and evening, and answered a Letter from E. Wright junr. New-York—
17. V. Monday

Mr James M’Clery, a Clerk in the office of the Register of the Treasury, called on me this morning and enquired if I had any detailed information respecting the vessels engaged in the whale fishery— I told him I had none here at present but thought much could be obtained from New-Bedford and Nantucket— He said there had been recently one or more Articles concerning it, in the Boston Atlas— He said he wanted the information to insert it in the document containing the returns of Commerce and Navigation— I called this morning at the Bank of the Metropolis and afterwards walked to the race grounds beyond the Columbian College before dinner— After dinner I walked again round the six buildings, and all the remainder of the day was employed in writing.— I have received several Letters
Letters from Strangers asking for my Autograph—and this writing of Autographs, and in Album’s has become seriously annoying— Sometimes nothing more is desired than a mere signature; but the call is usually for lines of poetry or more properly speaking, verses.— The thought struck me this morning of writing an Acrostic, on the word Autograph— I actually wrote two and finding the word to consist of nine Letters, it naturally led me to the nine lined Stanza of Spenser’s Fairy Queen, which I had never before attempted— But in the second of my Acrostics the word Phrenology presented itself to me, and then there was room for imagination far beyond my reach— I wrote however two more Stanzas and left the subject scarcely entered upon— I received from the Engineer Office of the War Department a Warrant for conditional admission to the Military Academy at West-Point as a Cadet, of Zealous B. Tower, son of Nichols B. Tower of Cohassett—and he is to be charged to the 12th. congressional District of Massachusetts. I enclosed it to his father; and answered also a Letter from O. H. Browne of Rome in the State of New-York, proposing to publish a Volume of Eulogies— Mary continues confined to her chamber; and both her children are now confined with her— Doctor Thomas was here for Dr Huntt.
18. V:30. Tuesday

Thomas B. J. Frye came in last Evening after we had retired. Slept here and breakfasted with us this morning— I attended this day two funerals— The first at Noon, that of Commodore Chauncey’s daughter, from Mrs Latimer’s House— There was a numerous collection of Carriages, all the heads of Departments except Mr Forsyth, and many Ladies— There was no performance of religious rites at the House, and I did not go with the procession of Carriages to the grave. Mrs Latimers house, is that in which the late Secretary of War, Lewis Cass resided, and the rooms where the attendants at the funeral were received, were the same where a little more than one year ago, in March 1836 I was at a splendid diplomatic dinner— It was the last time that I had been in the rooms; and many changes have since happened— The contemplation was more suitable to the occasion than cheering— I came home; dined and at 4 in the afternoon went and attended the funeral of Joseph Anderson, with whose life many recollections were associated— He was a native of Pennsylvania, born in 1757— At the age of 19. in 1776 entered the army as a lieutenant at the commencement of the revolutionary War—served through the whole Revolution during which he rose to the rank of Major— After the War he removed to the State of Delaware and practiced Law—in February 1791. he was appointed by President Washington one of the Judges of the Southwestern Territory; and when that became the State of Tennessee in 1797. he was elected one of her first Senators in the Senate of the United States—from that time till March 1815 he continued in that station; and then was appointed by Mr Madison, first Comptroller of the Treasury— This Office he held upwards of twenty years untill early in last Summer— He had then a stroke of palsy, which disabled him for the remainder of his days— He resigned his Office and he lived with his son William in this City— About a week since he had an attack of the gravel, which he had no strength of
strength of Constitution left to resist, and under which he expired yesterday morning in the eightieth year of his age— I served with him five years in the Senate of the United States from 1803 to 1808. during the latter part of which he was one of my confidential friends and correspondents— The correspondence continued some time after I left the Senate— When I returned from Europe in 1817, he was first comptroller of the Treasury—he retained that place through Mr Monroe’s administration and mine, and nearly seven years of that of General Jackson— He was a plain, laborious, honest man; a fluent and agreeable, but not a powerful public Speaker— A mind a little above the average capacity of men with moderate education, and not much— As comptroller of the Treasury he had sunk into little more than a drudge, and had grown heavy, as he grew old— I had not seen him since his retirement, and knew not that he was in the City, till this Morning’s Intelligencer announced his decease— The Coffin was left open as he was lying in it, and I saw the ruin of a face long so familiar and so friendly to me. Dr Laurie delivered a pious exhortation and a fervent prayer over it— Most of the subordinate Officers of the Government were there, but none of the heads of Department. Several women; not known to me— I followed the herse and the procession of Carriages to the grave; and saw the coffin deposited in his last home— The weather was chilling. I got home about Sunset, and wrote in the Evening— Mary and the two children are still confined to the chamber, and were visited by Dr Thomas—
19. VI. Wednesday

I answered a Letter from John G. Whittier inviting me on the part of the managers of the Massachusetts Anti-Slavery Society, to attend the meeting of the New-England Anti-Slavery Convention at Boston, to be held on the last Tuesday of May. I have not absolutely declined to attend, but have assigned reasons for not attending which will probably be decisive to my own mind— Upon this subject of Anti-Slavery, my principles and my position make it necessary for me to be more circumspect in my conduct than belongs to my Nature— I have therefore already committed indiscretions of which all the political parties avail themselves to proscribe me in the public opinion— The most insignificant error of conduct in me at this time would be my irredeemable ruin in this world, and both the ruling political parties are watching with intense anxiety for some overt act by me, to set the whole pack of their hireling Presses upon me. It is also to be considered that at this time the most dangerous of all the subjects for public contention is the Slavery question— In the South it is a perpetual agony of conscious guilt and terror, attempting to disguise itself under sophistical argumentation and braggart menaces. In the North, the People favour the whites and fear the blacks of the South— The Politicians count the South because they want their votes— The abolitionists are gathering themselves into Societies increasing their numbers and thriving upon persecution— But in proportion as they increase in numbers and in zeal they kindle the opposition against themselves into a flame; and the Passions of the Populace, are all engaged against them— The exposure through which I passed at the late Session of Congress was greater than I could have imagined possible: and having escaped
escaped from that fiery furnace, it behooves me well to consider my ways before I put myself in the way of being cast into it again— On the other hand may God preserve me from the craven Spirit of shrinking from danger in the discharge of my duty— Between these two errors let me pursue the path of rectitude unmov’d, and put my trust in God.— I called this morning at the Office of the Secretary of State— Mr Forsyth was not there; but I left the Letters of Mr John Herkimer and Mr Gros with the Chief Clerk for enquiry concerning the papers of the case— Met Mr Jarvis and walked with him nearly to the Capitol— While we were at dinner two persons called upon me on visits merely of curiosity— One from Poughkeepsie New-York named Palen— The other from Port Tobacco who did not tell me his name— At Evening twilight I walked again and called upon Mrs W. S. Smith— Genl. and Mrs. Macomb came in to spend the Evening with her. I returned home— Mary’s cough continues but she left her chamber this day— Evening cards—
20. V:30. Thursday

I received this morning a Letter from Mr J. Meredith of Baltimore, written on Tuesday afternoon, notifying me that I need not hurry myself to attend the United States Circuit Court there, as the case of Whitney vs Leakin would not come on before Friday, and perhaps not till next Monday; and promising to write me again in a day or two. Mr Fendall was here to renew a request for an accommodation which it is not in my power to make, and which I was reluctantly compelled to decline— In reviewing my files of papers, I found two Letters requiring information at the Treasury Department which I had overlooked— I took them and left them with the Secretary of the Treasury Mr Woodbury— One was from Mr B. Nye of Wareham, soliciting some interposition of the Secretary to relieve the merchants and Shipmasters at Wareham from the necessity of going 15 Miles to New-Bedford to enter their vessels at the Custom House— There is a Petition which was before Congress at both their Sessions, from Wareham, to be made a Port of Entry; and a section to that effect was introduced into the Custom-house Bill, but it was not reached in the business of the house. Mr Nye wrote to me requesting me to enquire if the Secretary of the Treasury could not appoint a deputy collector at Wareham with power to enter vessels there— I read the Petition and the Letter to Mr Woodbury, who said a deputy collector was in some places appointed, and said if I would leave the Papers, he would examine the subject and send me an answer.— The other Letter was from William Ellis of Dedham, making enquiries in behalf of a family there by the name of Guild; having some claim to prize money from the proceeds of captures made by Paul Jones and his squadron in 1779— It appears there was a sum paid into the Treasury many years ago for the benefit of those captors; and in the naval appropriation bill of the last Session, an appropriation was made, which the Secretary of
of the Treasury was required to pay to such legal representatives of the claimants as should substantiate their right to a part of the proceeds— Mr Woodbury took Mr Ellis’s Letter, which he said he would refer to the first auditor and make me acquainted with the result— I then walked to the Capitol and visited the Library. It was past two and I had but a short time to remain there— I found there the second Volume of the English translation of de Tocqueville’s work upon democracy in the United States, over several chapters of which I cast my eyes— Tocqueville observed much more of what he saw in the United States, than most other European travellers; but I soon found that he had observed many things very superficially. At three the hour of closing the library came and I walked home— Mrs W. S. Smith came in after dinner— I walked round the square and the six Buildings; and we had cards in the Evening— I began the answer to a Letter from Elijah Hayward, of Columbus. Ohio, heretofore Commissioner of the general Land Office. Mary’s cough continues very troublesome, but she goes out— The children are yet confined to the Nursery— Wilson was here for a certificate of character and Settlement—
21. V:30. Friday

Wilson was here again this morning and brought me sundry unsettled Bills— I gave him a certificate of character for himself and his wife— They have lived with us three years; and left us the 10th. of this Month, the day that I went to Baltimore— They are English: the woman of an excellent character, and so useful as an attendant and occasional Nurse to my wife, that we both lament the loss of her service— Wilson himself is a man of good faculties, and mechanical faculties more than common—but proud, self-conceited, and sometimes disrespectful; though he has never been so to me— Change of Servants is always very disagreeable to me, and in the course of my life, I have had occasion to turn away few— But the relation between Master and Servant, is one of the most controversial conditions of human existence— It is difficult for the parties to discharge their respective duties to each other; and I must say that in my experience of life, the character of a good master has appeared to me to be more rare than that of a good Servant.— Dr Huntt was here this morning; looking better than when I saw him last Sunday at his house; but with a fearful cough upon him, and spitting of blood— I finished my Letter to Elijah Hayward, and wrote one in answer to an old one received from A. W. Thayer at Philadelphia— During the Session of Congress I received so many Letters of enquiries to be made at the Departments, besides the multitudes with abolition petitions, that I had scarcely time to read and file many of them. I could not possibly keep my files in regular order. I filed them from time to time, and left them on my table— Since the close of the Session of Congress I have been constantly occupied in ovehawling them; assorting them in alphabetical files; making the desired enquiries at the Departments, and answering the Letters— I am coming to the fiftieth day of this labour and found a Letter from Alexander Beard, dated at Rome in the State
State of New-York, asking information of me, whether his mother, being a widow of a revolutionary pensioner, is entitled to a Pension, and requesting an answer by return of the mail— I received this Letter dated the 4th. of February on the 10th. of that month, in the midst of my troubles in the House—put it upon file, and there it has escaped my attention till this day— I took it and left it with Mr Edwards, the Commissioner of Pensions, requesting him to enable me to answer it— I then walked round the Capitol, and in walking composed a Sonnet— This is an easy exercise, and the most convenient form for autographs and albums— I have several Letters on hand from strangers requesting these; and am often at great loss how to answer them— Too many remain unanswered— My difficulty is barrenness of Imagination— One poetical idea, is enough for a Sonnet; but when I compare together those that I have written at different times, I am humiliated on finding how unconsciously, my thoughts always run, in one narrow channel— Among my musings of this day, I was analyzing the sentiment, the versification and the Poetry, of the song “When the Fancy-stirring bowl” admiring its exquisite beauty, shuddering at its licentious morality, and envying the powers of its author.— What creative imagery! what delicacy of expression to convey thoughts of the coarsest sensuality! what embellishments of drunkenness and lust! what a veil of tenderness, and benevolence cast over their nakedness! what graphic description! and what adaptation of sense to sound, in the greatest harmony of numbers— The English language swarms with beautiful Songs; but this is one of the most charming of them all. Mrs W. S. Smith dined with us— Evening spent at cards.
22 VI:30. Saturday—

Still rummaging over my files, I found a Letter from Octavius Longworth of New-York respecting an application for a Pension of a man named Salmon Tryon— It has remained unanswered since January 1835. when it was received. It contained a copy of a Letter from Tryon himself to Taylor the bookseller in this City, so insulting to the Commissioner of Pensions, an excellent, and most faithful Officer, that I had neglected it as deserving no answer— But I took it this morning to Mr Edwards, and left it with him, asking some explanation of the facts. In the course of the day I received his answers, both relating to this case, and to the Letter from Alexander Beard— Tryon’s claim for a Pension was founded on his having been keeper of a Jail during the revolutionary War— I received also an answer from the Secretary of the Treasury, upon the application of B. Nye of Wareham—unfavourable—and a Note from Mr Dayton, Chief Clerk in the Department of State, informing me that search has been made, in the files and records of the Department for the papers enquired after by the Letters of John Herkimer and of Mr Gros, without success. Mr Pedrich the Sculptor called on me, and told me he had been for several weeks at Frederick, Maryland making a colossal Statue of St. John the Evangelist, for the pediment of a new Roman Catholic Church that they are building there— I asked him if the Statue was of Marble? He said no—
no—but of a material much harder than marble, a composition of the Cement used in the building of the canal, with some other ingredients of his own choice— The composition was so much harder than marble that by working upon it only a few weeks, he had worn out a hammer, which he had used for years before in working upon marble, without wasting it at all, so that he had now been obliged to procure a new one— He said he intended to take out a Patent for his composition—but he had also discovered about eight miles from Frederick and within three miles of the Baltimore and Ohio-Rail-way, a quarry of the finest marble he had ever beheld—far superior to that of Carrara—white as snow, of the finest grain, and without a speck— And the rock instead of being buried under ground, rose several feet above it— That he had purchased four Acres of the Land bearing this marble, from which he could easily procure blocks of various sizes, as he might occasionally want them— He said he was now employed by the Commissioner of the Public Buildings, for various works of Sculpture, upon the Treasury and Patent-Offices now under construction and at the Capitol— I have some need of Faith to credit his wonderful discoveries of a cement much harder than marble, and of a quarry of marble far superior to that of Carrara— He spoke of the two Busts of me by Persico, and Powers—preferring the latter— I answered a Letter from Mr Timothy Pitkin of the 18th. of February last, respecting a Statement in my Eulogy on James Madison. I found it necessary to recur to some old documents of 1805–6– and 7.—part of them I found in Waite’s State papers and the Executive Journals of the Senate— For the rest I called at the National Intelligencer Office, and enquired of Mr Gales for my set of the Edition of State Papers published by Gales and Seaton in 21. Folio Volumes; to which I am entitled as an Ex-President of the United States. Gales referred me to Asbury Dickins the Secretary of the Senate— I met him as I was going to the Capitol, and he promised to send me the set of those Volumes, assigned to me by the joint Resolution of Congress— At the Library I found in the second Volume of the State papers on Foreign Relations the Letters and Note from Talleyrand, upon our boundary question with Spain, which I wanted to answer Mr Pitkin’s Letter— Mr Jarvis was at the Library; and while I was there, President Van Buren came in with Mr Troup heretofore Lieutenant Governor of New-York, whom he introduced to me— Jarvis told me he had seen Mr Nicholas Biddle in the City this morning— I thought he must be mistaken, but on returning home I found he had been here, but was to return this Evening to Baltimore— He said he was to attend the Circuit Court at Baltimore on the trial of Whitney’s case next Monday, and that I should be then expected there also— Mr Frye spent an hour with us this Evening, and we had afterwards a whist-party.— At the Office of the Commissioner of Pensions this morning I met Mr M’pherson, Consul of the United States at Carthagena in the Republic of New-Grenada, now absent from his post upon leave— I asked him sundry questions upon the present Condition of that and the other South American Republics, most of which he was not able to answer.
23. V:30. Sunday

Rainy day— I attended the morning service at the Presbyterian Church, and heard Mr Fowler from James 4:13 [“]Go to, now, ye that say, To-day or to-morrow we will go into such a city, and continue there a year, and buy and sell, and get gain; 14. Whereas ye know now what shall be on the morrow. For what is your life? It is even a vapour, that appeareth for a little time, and then vanisheth away. 15. For that ye ought to say, If the Lord will, we shall live, and do this or that. 16. But now ye rejoice in your boastings: all such rejoicing is evil. 17. Therefore to him that knoweth to do good, and doeth it not, to him it is sin.”— Mr Fowler discoursed suitably upon this text to a very slender auditory, and it gave me much to meditate upon—as the time is hourly approaching when I must be called to my account—and I was thus occupied a considerable part of the day— There was no afternoon service at St. John’s Church; and the rain was so heavy that I did not go out— But I wrote an answer to the Letter from Mr. D. Nye of Wareham which had been two Months on my file, and read some pages of Mr. Madison’s report of the Speeches in the federal Convention of 1787.— I was remarkably struck with the proposition and Speech of Dr Franklin on the 28th. of June.— They had been debating then nearly two Months, and appeared to approach no result. The perpetually recurring Jealousy was between the large and the small States— The 15. Resolutions proposed by Edmund Randolph had formed the text of all the discussions. They were the germ of the Constitution as finally adopted— Then came the plan of Mr Patterson of New-Jersey; which was to retain the old Confederation and Congress with some additional powers— This was the plan of the small States— Then the plan of Hamilton, with a President and Senate during good behaviour; a negative upon State Laws, and the Governors of the States appointed by the National Executive— The manner in which Hamilton introduced his plan, was indirect and hesitating; the characteristics of his mind and conduct— He expressly stated that he did not offer it as a subject for deliberation, but merely to convey his ideas of what was the best Government for this Country— Yet he supported it by a Speech which occupied a whole day; and he explicitly declared that neither the plan founded upon Edmund Randolph’s Resolutions, nor the plan of Mr Patterson was satisfactory to him— Afterwards came Luther Martin, who made a Speech of a day and a half to maintain the Sovereignty of the States, and against proportional representation, and against a Legislature in two branches. The proportional representation was after long and obstinate resistance carried for one branch— It was contended for with equal tenacity in the other when Dr Franklin moved that they should have prayers performed every morning; calling upon the clergymen of the several Churches of the City in turn— It was a singular proposition to be made, after the Convention had been sitting nearly two Months, and the Doctor’s Speech
Speech was still more remarkable— He was then upwards of eighty years of age and he died within three years after— In this speech he declared with great solemnity his belief that God governs in the affairs of men— At an earlier period of his life he had certainly been a skeptic. His motion was seconded by Roger Sherman—but was opposed by Hamilton and others and finally evaded by an adjournment— It had perhaps a good effect as an admonition of mutual concessions and conciliation to all the members.
24. V:45. Monday

We had intermitted making fires in my Cabinet and in our bed chamber, for the last ten days, but the weather has become so cold that we could no longer dispense entirely with them— The thermometer in my chamber ranging from 50 to 55—but the inconvenience of the anthracite coal is, that with it, you can have no small fires— It must burn intensely or goes out— I suffered considerably this day from cold— I answered a Letter received on the 8th. of February last from Sarah M. Grimké written at New-York, and containing enquiries concerning the Coastwise Slave-trade— The size of the vessels, and the number of the Slaves that they carry with them— This is the last of the long standing Letters upon my files which accumulated during the late Session of Congress, and which I have been constantly occupied in answering for fifty days since its close— Excepting only Letters asking for autographs, which puzzle me more than all the rest; and no small number of which remain unanswered altogether— There was in the National Intelligencer of this Morning an Editorial Article written after my Conversation with Mr Gales of last Saturday, and to which is added an extract from my suppressed Speech of 4. April 1834. on the removal of the Deposits— I had mentioned to Mr Gales that Speech as foreshewing much of what is now coming to pass; but the passage of the Speech to which I alluded was not that extracted in the Intelligencer of this Morning— This induced me to read over the suppressed Speech, and to my surprize the passage to which I referred was not in it— I concluded it was in another Speech, made on the preceding 20th. of March, upon presenting the Resolutions of the Legislature of Massachusetts— I went to the Office of the National Intelligencer and finding neither of the Editors there walked round the Capitol, and on returning found Mr Seaton at the Office— Gales came in afterwards— I asked if their Register of Debates for the first Session of the 23d. Congress 1833–34 was printed so that I could refer to a debate contained in it— Seaton found upon examination that although wholly printed, the volumes were not yet so folded and stitched that they could be referred to—but he promised me that a set of them should be prepared for me in a day or two— Seaton had just returned from Boston and Cambridge, where he had been to replace his Son, at the University, where he is a member of the Senior Class— He left him at board with professor Ware the elder— After dinner Mrs Adams, and the young Ladies rode out, and T. B. J. Frye returned with them to pass the Night here. I have not received the Quincy Patriot of the 15th. and was apprehensive the Paper had
had fallen through, the partnership of the two Editors having been dissolved on the 1st. of this Month—but in the National Inquirer of Philadelphia, of Saturday last, and this day received, I find an extract from the Quincy Patriot of the 15th. being the closing paragraphs of my last Address, (of 20. March) to the Inhabitants of the 12th. Congressional District of Massachusetts— It has therefore been published— The Hingham Gazette has republished one or two of my Addresses without comment. But not one of the Boston Newspapers so far as I have seen, has even given notice that such Addresses existed; although while they have been in the course of publication the Anti-Slavery Resolutions of the Legislature of Massachusetts were debated and adopted— This universal Silence upon my Addresses, compared with the vehement yet inconsistent proceedings of the Legislature, is indicative of an excited and yet tremulous state of public opinion upon the subject. Its admonition is, composure and caution— The Legislature of Massachusetts, adjourned on the 19th. The two Houses had passed an act raising the pay of their members from 2 dollars to 2 dollars and a half a day— It was returned by Governor Edward Everett with objections; and they repassed it with majorities of more than two thirds in both Houses— This falling out between Everett, and the members of the Legislature, on a question about their pay, will be likely to have a serious influence upon the future politics of the State.
25. V:30. Tuesday

The cold weather and the necessity for a fire in my chamber continues and with it a chill upon my fingers partially disables my fingers from writing.
