So I attempt to read with no better success— I wrote a short Letter to Virgil David, and walked to the Capitol and visited the Library of Congress— I examined the second Volume of Gales and Seaton’s collection of American State Papers on their foreign Relations— I found among them many valuable public documents which I had not before seen or had very slightly perused— Among the rest several Memoirs of Robert R. Livingston addressed to Napoleon, dissuading him from the settlement of his Colony in Louisiana, and then to cede it to the United States— It seems as if there was something providential in the turn of all those transactions— The Spanish Monarchy, was an old worn out rotten Government dropping to pieces by the weight of its own corruptions— Napoleon shaking it almost to atoms first by War—then stripping it of its European possessions; encroaching upon it over the Pyrenees to the Ebro; forcing its pusillanimous Bourbons to abdicate; and the father and mother with her despicable paramour Godoy, to go and die in ignominious obscurity at Rome; and the son Ferdinand—“Ame lache et pusillanime,[”] as General Pardo characterized him to me, to abdicate and pine in prison at Bayonne— In the preliminary steps to all this process, because Louisiana had once been a French Colony, Napoleon undertakes to recover it, and to settle there a Military Colony of his veteran Soldiers— Having a triangular view for futurity upon Mexico, upon Canada and the British Northern Colonies, and upon the United States— R. R. Livingston was then Minister from the United States, at his Court, and ingratiated himself, by falling in without scruple, into the Ultra-royal Etiquette of the imperial Upstart—and coming from the stern Republican Government of the U.S.
United States, this species of adulation was more flattering than it could be from the representatives of Monarchs— Mr Livingston thus obtained access to the ear of Napoleon, who received and read his paper.— They had no effect until the War with Great Britain came on—but then they found the mind prepared for the reception of argument, and when the War was once resolved on Louisiana became a burden which it was the clear interest of France to get rid of as soon as possible and upon as good terms as she could obtain. The finger of Heaven appears in all this, and when we think of Mr Jay’s proposing in 1786 to renounce the Navigation of the Mississippi for 25 years, and in 1794 negotiating for the delivery of the Posts on the Canadian Lakes, and observe the condition of things now, when the City of Mexico can scarcely be kept out of our clutches, we can but contemplate with wonder the ways of God to Man— But upon looking at our two frontiers North and South it is no pleasing consideration to find that while our boundary has been constantly advancing on the South, it has been receding on the North— I found at the Library in the National Intelligencer of 20. March 1834. the passage of my Speech on the removal of the Deposits to which I had alluded in the conversation with Mr Gales last Saturday— It was not in the suppressed Speech, but in the Speech made on presenting the Resolutions of the Legislature of Massachusetts— Returning home I called at the National Intelligencer Office, where I found that my Speech of 20 March 1834. was in the Register of the Debates of that Session now printed, but the 4. Volumes of which are not yet bound— Featherstonhaugh was there— Evening at Whist— The children came down to dinner— Musing for verses.
26. V:30. Wednesday.

Chilling Cold and winter stock of coal exhausted. I had time to write a Letter to my Son; but began with an attempt to assort and file my papers which have been accumulating during the late Session of Congress, but soon found the morning wasted, and little advance made in my assortment. I found however a small file of Letters from my father to Arthur Lee from 1778 to 1786 with one from Mr Lee to him—without date or signature but written in 1788 immediately after his return from Europe in 1788. which were given to me by the younger Richard Henry Lee, in 1827. and 1828. I now read them all, and they took me back a full half century, and more; even to the days of my boyhood— The Letters written at different times mark each the feelings and the interests of a different epoch. The first, written in September 1778. contains a proposition to employ William Temple Franklin as Secretary to the joint Commission; and another that Mr Lee who resided at Chaillot should come and reside at the same house of Le Ray de Chaumont where Dr Franklin and my father lived, for the convenience of holding their conferences with an improved economy of time and of expense— The next is of 24. March 1779. at Brest, when my father was about to return to the United States— I was then reading Don Quichotte de la Manche in the Cabin of the Frigate Alliance, or walking the Streets of Brest with Captain Landais— Then a Letter of 9. June 1779 from L’Orient
L’Orient.— Next three Letters from Paris, dated 15 and 31. March 1780. in the hand-writing of John Thaxter, and one of 25. May; all directed to Mr Lee at L’Orient where he was waiting for a passage in the frigate Alliance to the United States— Then a Letter from the Hague 29. Augustus 1782. to Mr Lee then in Congress at Philadelphia— One from Paris 12. April 1783 between the Preliminary Articles and the definitive Treaty of Peace—one of 6. April 1784 from the Hague—one of 31. Jany 1785 from Auteuil; and one of 6. Septr. 1785. from Grosvenor Square, Westminster— The Letter from Arthur Lee to him is of 8. August 1788. without date of place and unsigned— No doubt a copy— It acknowledges the receipt of a Letter from my father announcing his return to his home at Braintree— This Series of Letters marks all the changes of my father’s residence from the time of his first Mission to France till his last return from Europe home. I selected the Letter of 24. March 1779. written at Brest, to send as an Autograph to Lewis J. Cist at Cincinnati, Ohio, taking first a copy of it for preservation— There is a character of romantic wildness about the memory of my travels in Europe, from 1778 to 1785. which gives to it a tinge, as if it was the recollection of something in another world— Life was new—every thing was surprizing—every thing carried with it a deep interest. It is almost surprizing to me now that I escaped from the fascination of Europe’s attractions, and that Voltaire’s affecting line “Plus je vis d’Etrangers plus j’aimai ma Patrie,[”] was always true to the Letter with me— My return home in 1785, from Auteuil, leaving my father when he was going upon his Mission to England, decide the Fate and Fortunes of my after Life— It was my own choice, and the most judicious choice that I ever made— My short discipline of 15 Months at Harvard University, was the introduction to all the prosperity that has ever befallen me, and perhaps saved me from early ruin— I called at the National Intelligencer Office, but neither Gales nor Seaton was there— Second walk after dinner, and Cards in the Evening.
27. V:30. Thursday

Intermitted fire-making again in my chamber, rather because the stock of coal is exhausted (30 tons since 10. November) than because the want of it was not felt— John Wilson was here, and I promised to settle with him in a few days— I returned to him his guinea and two half-guineas which he gave me to keep for him nearly two years ago. He said the new French Minister, Mr Edouard Pontois, offered him ten dollars a month for his wife’s service, and twenty dollars a month, and his clothing for himself, and he thought he should accept it, which I advised him by all means to do— A man came styling himself a Swedish Officer; having intended to apply to Mr Lorich, the late Swedish Chargé d’Affaires, now deceased— He said he was going to Richmond Virginia; but had no money, and even a five dollar bill would be very acceptable— I have known multitudes of such Solicitiors, and not one of them to my recollection but was a cheat
cheat— I declined giving him any thing— Henry Wilson was a soldier in the last War, and claims a pension as having been disabled in the service— He came to ask me for his discharge which he said he gave me nearly three years ago at Quincy. And he said he had now come here himself, because Commodore Chauncey who gave him his discharge was here— I had but an indistinct recollection of having received his discharge; but told him I presumed it would be found at the Navy Department— I called at the Office of the 5th. Auditor, and had some conversation with Mr Pleasonton, upon the claim of Mrs Tudor, to certain allowances in the account of her Son William Tudor junr— Pleasonton said he would revise the account, and let me know how it stood— I walked round the Capitol and took a second shorter walk after dinner.— Sent the two Autographs of my father and of Thomas Jefferson, to Lewis J. Cist at Cincinnati— The Ladies spent the Evening at Mrs W. S. Smiths— I went there after nine, and spent half an hour with them at whist— Rode home— I have cleared off the arrears of my correspondence, with the exception of several Letters from strangers asking for Autographs, a recent fashion like that of keeping Album’s— The Album is I believe a German invention, never introduced till of late years into this Country, and now perverted by its multiplication, and its degeneracy into a mere catalogue of insignificant names— Those in which sentiments are added are records of human imbecility—bushels of chaff without the two grains of wheat— Ashamed to write my bare name in answer to a request for an Autograph, I have usually added a few lines of rhyme without reason— Casting about for a thought, two days ago, I looked into Horace and fell upon the 6th. Ode of the 3d. Book ad Romanos— I took the thought of the first lines—modernized it—localized it and paraphrased it, till I turned it into an Ode as long as the original, but so little like it that no one would ever recognize it— This day I finished it, and call it a prophesy, addressed to the sons of the Pilgrims.— A poor thing and not fit even for an autograph or an Album— This has happened to me five or six times— I angle for a thought, and after four or five nibbles catch one, and when the line brings it up it turns out to be a sculpin for a mackerel or a cod. My prophesy is upon a grave and solemn subject.
28. V:45. Friday.

I received this morning a Letter from Mr Meredith of Baltimore, informing me, that the case of Reuben M Whitney vs Leakin and Barnes has been continued over to the next term of the Circuit Court to be held on the first Monday of November next. I wrote immediately to my Son, and wrote also a short Letter to Moses Shaw of Wiscasset concerning the Ships Journal of the Boston Frigate Captain Samuel Tucker on her Voyage to France in February and March 1778— Taking a further view of my file of Letters I find one of the 4th. of March from Bellamy Storer, respecting the Petition of Huldah Penniman for a Pension, and this reminded me of the Petition of Jerusha Ripley. I presented both the Petitions at the late Session of Congress; but from the delay in printing
printing the Journal, I have waited to ascertain what their condition was at the close of the Session. I found further a Letter of Samuel Alden Frazar of Duxbury, dated 27. Decr. last, and received on the 2d. of Jany. respecting a claim of his own upon France, for spoliations prior to 1800. and also a claim of a widow named Partridge for a pension—unanswered— I called at the Office of the Commissioner of Pensions, who took minutes of these three cases, and said he would send to the Office of the Clerk of the House of Representatives for the papers relating to the two Petitions— But I went to the Clerk’s Office myself, which was empty; all the Clerks having gone to dinner & leaving only a black man to take care of the Office— Two of them soon afterwards came in, and gave me the papers with the Petitions of Jerusha Ripley and Huldah Penniman, which I took home with me— There were Bills reported by the Committee of Revolutionary Pensions in both cases, neither of which passed—but they were both embraced by the explanatory Bill of the 3d. of March last— I cannot justify to myself the lapse of time that I have suffered to pass before giving due attention to these cases; especially after being reminded of that of Huldah Penniman, by the Letter of Bellamy Storer— This inattention has not been voluntary, but proceeded from a want of perfect method, in transacting business of individuals before Congress or the Departments. The Letters to me, enclosing or recommending the Petitions had been presented with the Petitions themselves, to the House, and are with the Papers of the file— Not being upon my own files, the recollection had escaped me, from whom they came— The abolition Petitions which I received in the course of the Session, early 300 in number; a large portion of them accompanied with Letters, and the fiery persecution which they excited against me so entirely absorbed my faculties, that they disconcerted all my system of orderly method, and warned me that if it please God to spare me for attendance at the 25th. Congress I must adopt an improved method at last for assistance to my failing Memory— These two cases of Jerusha Ripley, and Huldah Penniman ought to have been dispatched within ten days after the close of the Session of Congress— The Letter enclosing the Petition of Huldah Penniman was from Reuben Baldwin of Boston— The Letters concerning Jerusha Ripley from Jonathan Parker of Plympton and Jacob H. Loud of Plymouth— Antoine Giusta was here this morning, and told me he had given up for the present his purpose of going to settle in the West— That the offer had been made to him and to his wife to go in and keep the President’s house as they did when I was there; but they had declined taking the place— His inclination was to take a small house, with a garden of ten or twelve Acres, and live by cultivating vegetables and fruit trees— Captain Wade—R. D. A. of the 3d. Regiment of Artillery was here with Mr Frye— I returned by Card the New Minister from France, Mr Pontois, who has taken B. O. Tayloe’s house— Mr Tayloe, with his wife is going to Europe— After dinner I took a second walk of about an hour. The weather is warm without and cold within doors— The children after a fortnight’s interruption resumed their Bible reading—Numbers—ch. 29— Cards.
29. V. Saturday

“Minuentur atrae Carmine curae.” Mr Clubb is the Messenger to the Office of the Secretary of the Senate, and brought me this morning the set of twenty-one Volumes in the Folio of Gales and Seaton’s collection of American State Papers, to which as a former President of the United States I am entitled, and for which I signed a receipt; having before received another set as a Member of the House of Representatives— This is an invaluable collection for the History of the Country, and has been published at great expense by order of Congress— Dr Huntt was here this morning and is apparently recovering, and Mrs W. S. Smith called after dinner, expecting her husband back from New-York where he has been this fortnight— I received a Letter from my Son which I forthwith answered; and wrote also to Lewis Tappan at New-York— I took the Papers of the two Pension claims of Jerusha Ripley and Hulday Penniman, to the Commissioner of Pensions who said he would have them examined this day— There were two Strangers at the office with him— I varied the order of my exercise; took the short walk in the morning, and the long one after dinner, round to the Potowmack bridge, and twice across the Tiber— Evening Cards— There is certainly something in the atmosphere of Spring that sets my brain in commotion for the composition of verses— Of the multitude of Rhymes that I have written, which have now become voluminous, I believe four fifths have been written in the Spring; excepting the versions of Wieland’s Oberon, and of the Psalms, each of which occupied me more than a year— Being still in search of thoughts for autographs I this day composed a Love-song, which if I could give it to a youth just out of his teens, to insert in his mistress’s Album would be very suitable, and not destitute either of Passion or of Harmony; but perfectly unfit for me to write, either as an Autograph, or in an Album. As I was again poaching in Horace for a thought, I met with the sentence at the head of this page; being part of the last two lines of the 11th. Ode of the 4th. book—to Phyllis— An invitation to a festival, to be kept by him about the middle of April; being the birthday of Maecenas, which he tells her is to him almost as sacred as his own— He describes all the preparations for the sacrifice of a lamb—the altar decked with chaste vervein—the boys and girls (a hired choir I suppose ) running to and fro—the flame and curling smoke of the altar— He tells Phyllis that her passion for Telephus, a young man much above her in rank, is useless, for that a rich and wanton young woman has possession of him, and he reminds her of the fate of Phaeton and Bellerophon for aspiring too high That she is the last of his loves, for that he will never catch fire for any other woman— So that she had better come, and learn with him to sing with her beloved voice his verses— And then comes that beautiful sentence with which the Ode concludes “Minuentur atrae Carmine curae”— Carking cares, assuaged by Song— This is an Ode of Horace; and what is an Ode? Sentiment clothed with imagery, and delivered in measure— Is not this a just definition of all Poetry— Now the mythology of Phaëton and Bellerophon—the Roman manners; the sacrifice of the lamb on the patron’s birth-day—the invitation by a bachelor to a courtezan, for such Phyllis must have been, to come, and join him in a pious and religious orgie, to drink wine and sing his verses with him telling her that it is idle for her to think of catching Telephus, but that she shall be the last of his Horace’s loves—all this has passed off and given way to other modes of existence—but the minuentur
“minuentur atrae Carmine curae” will last as long as the human race. It is the intermixture of such Sentiments with antient manners, loose morals an extinguished religion and language that constitute the charm of Horace’s Poetry— The Sapphick Stanza with the Adonic closing line was evidently his favourite measure, and is the only one of his measures which falls harmoniously upon my ear.— I took up this day an old Newspaper; the Tablet of 4. August 1795. printed at Boston, and was about tearing it up, when casting my eye upon a Selection—not naming the author, I saw, it was an Ode on the Pleasure arising from Vicissitude, and upon reading it found it was part of Gray’s fragment, which on the 23d of last Month I copied from Matthias’s Edition of his works in the Congress Library— Here again is harmonious Sentiment clothed in imagery— Why did he not finish it?
30. V:15. Sunday.

“And from the days of John the Baptist until now the kingdom of heaven suffereth violence, and the violent take it by force.” Matthew 11.12. This was the text from which at the Presbyterian Church Mr Fowler preached this morning, but he made nothing of his subject— He neither explained what Jesus meant by saying from the days of John the Baptist until now; for John was yet living, though in prison, and had sent two of his disciples to him to enquire, art thou he that should come, or do we look for another? a question which he had answered with great caution and some obscurity—referring John merely to the miracles which he had wrought, among which he classes the preaching of the gospel to the poor— Nor what he meant by saying that the kingdom of heaven was taken by violence, and that the violent took it by force— Mr Fowler made from this text a commonplace discourse of exhortation to his hearers to take the kingdom of Heaven by force; that is, by penitence and faith in the atonement; and by hating the world— I suppose that by the words from the days of John the Baptist until now, he meant from the days when John began to baptize, and to preach repentance in the wilderness—but John only proclaimed that the kingdom of Heaven was at hand— Jesus says further that the prophets had prophesied until John—but that John was a prophet and more than a prophet— That of the sons of men none greater than John had appeared, but that the least in the kingdom of Heaven was greater than he— He said also expressly that John was the Elias or Elijah, promised by several of the prophets and especially by the last words of the last prophet, Malachi.— But how was the kingdom of Heaven taken by violence, and how did the violent take it by force— It must have been figurative language like that in the preceding chapter, when he said that he came not to bring Peace, but the sword— Jesus never disclosed explicitly that he came to abolish all the Mosaic Institutions— He said that he came not to destroy but to fulfil; that is to fulfil the promise of the Messiah.— but the Messiah as the Jews understood their prophesies, was to restore the kingdom of David, and Christ’s Mission was to establish the Kingdom of Heaven— I think his saying that the kingdom of Heaven, was taken by violence, was an obscure intimation that his kingdom could not be adopted by the Jews, without the total overthrow of the Mosaic Covenant, and of the Levitical Ritual— His Religion was certainly not during his life propagated by violence. Mrs Frye
Mrs. Frye, and her Son Thomas dined with us— Elizabeth spent the day at judge Cranch’s— After dinner at St. John’s Church Mr Higbee read prayers for the 5th. Sunday after Easter and discoursed from Luke 15.10. “Likewise, I say unto you, There is joy in the presence of the angels of God, over one Sinner that repenteth.” Mr Higbee delivered his Sermon with great animation, and is a very eloquent preacher. Repentance however is a subject so thoroughly exhausted under the Christian economy, that it is scarcely susceptible of any new elucidation— The most interesting part of the discourse, was a short discussion in support of the belief in the existence of Angels; which he said was doubted by many, but which he himself firmly believed— He adduced no argument for this belief, but merely authorities, from the Scripture, which to be sure are very abundant— The Scriptures both of the old, and new Testament swarm with Angels; but of their existence there is no other Evidence but the Scriptures— The visible creation, and the intellect of man afford confirmative evidence to the testimonies of Holy writ, of the existence of God; but not of Angels— The idea of Angels, of Cherubim, of Seraphim, loving and beneficent Spirits, ministering to the throne of God, is pleasing to the imagination, but that of powerful evil Spirits is painful, and afflictive— I wrote a short Letter to Mrs Alphonsa Blake, daughter of the late William Carmichael, one of the earliest diplomatic agents of the United States, in the Revolutionary War; and in the Evening I went to the Unitarian Church and heard Dr Follen preach, from John 5.28. “Marvel not at this; for the hour is coming, in the which all that are in their graves shall hear his voice. 29. And shall come forth; they that have done good, unto the resurrection of life; and they that have done evil, unto the resurrection of damnation.”— He had read from the 10th. to the 20th. verse of the 33d. chapter of Ezekiel; and explained that the words life and death, in that chapter do not mean temporal life and death; nor yet eternal life and death; but that they mean happiness and misery—upon which I pause— This chapter of Ezekiel has I think excluded him from the Jewish Canon of the Scriptures, at least in some of their communities. Dr Follen expounded from his text and from this passage of the book of Ezekiel, the Unitarian creed respecting the retributive Justice of God, and to a future state of rewards and punishments— He urged that rewards and punishments must necessarily be proportioned to merits and demerits, and that neither could be eternal— That both must be susceptible of degrees, and that when the motive for punishment, the love of the offender has been accomplished and the object, his reformation attained, the punishment must cease, and the Sinner restored to the purity of innocence. Dr Follen gave notice, that as circumstances would detain him here he should on Tuesday Evening at half past seven deliver another Lecture, containing a Summary of the whole course of Lectures on Unitarianism, which he has given in this City— It was past ten O’Clock when I got home. T. B. J. Frye was here.

Day. My course of life during the month now expiring has been quiet, regular, and industrious—under a pressure of difficulties which the general distress of the Times has rendered doubly severe, and from which my only relief is to avert my thoughts from it without falling into desperation— I rise between five and six; write till the breakfast hour at Nine. Then three hours of Newspaper reading—two of time wasted I know not how, a walk of an hour and a half to and round the Capitol, and three times a week an hour or two at the Capitol—dine at 4. Half an hour’s afternoon walk—at dusk—two hours Evening Letter writing, or Cards— Bed from 10 to 11— The Diary for the Month complete.
